verses.text: How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O prince’s daughter! The joints of thy thighs \add are\add* like jewels, The work of the hands of a cunning workman.
Thy navel \add is like\add* a round goblet, \add which\add* wanteth not liquor: Thy belly \add is like\add* a heap of wheat set about with lilies.
Thy two breasts \add are\add* like two young roes \add that are\add* twins.

Thy neck \add is\add* as a tower of ivory; Thine eyes \add like\add* the \add fish\add*pools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim: Thy nose \add is\add* as the tower of Lebanon which looketh toward Damascus.
Thine head upon thee \add is\add* like Carmel, And the hair of thine head like purple; The king \add is\add* held in the galleries.
How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!
This thy stature is like to a palm tree, And thy breasts to clusters \add of grapes\add*.
I said, I will go up to the palm tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof: Now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, And the smell of thy nose like apples;
And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine, For my beloved, that goeth \add down\add* sweetly, Causing the lips of \add those that are\add* asleep to speak.
I \add am\add* my beloved’s, and his desire \add is\add* towards me.
Come, my beloved, let us go forth \add into\add* the field; Let us lodge in the villages.
Let us get up early to the vineyards; Let us see if the vine flourish, \add whether\add* the tender grape appear, \add And\add* the pomegranates bud forth: There will I give thee my loves.
The mandrakes give a smell, And at our gates \add are\add* all \add manner of\add* pleasant \add fruits\add*, New and old, \add Which\add* I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.
